description.text:
http://www.makerbot.com/blog/2011/09/29/openscad-challenge-regular-icosahedron/ It didn't take me too many lines of code, but I did use two libraries so make of it what you will. ;) BTW, just because it's OpenSCAD code, don't assume it's 100% parametric. It's pretty close though, someone just needs to come around and iron out the formulas. Uses:
WilliamAAdams's Platonic Solids: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10725
Tony Buser's Bitmap module: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2054

For extra geek factor, I've included some options with some fantasy fonts. There's even an elvish option! All the text, except for the blocky original, was created with my own text2surface.py (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10404) with commands like:
./text2surface.py -t 20 -f "Tengwar Annatar" -z 7 -rn -d 12 -o 20_tengwarannatar.stl
Positioned for printing.

• Print
  • Roll
  • Win!

title: Paint bottle shaker for Vallejo Model Color and Model Air bottles

description.text: A simple 3D-printable paint bottle holder for Vallejo Model Color and Model Air (possibly Game Color and others) bottles. It attaches with a small clamp (also 3D-printable) to a jigsaw blade using two 4-40 screws and nuts. I know, some people like their paints stirred as opposed to shaken, oh well. Although the holder provides a snug fit, the rubber band on the photo is for 'insurance'. The small recess in the clamp part is for the jigsaw blade to slip into, as seen on the photo. Once the blade is in, tighten the nuts...and give it a shake!

title: Jakku Salvage Crawler (Littlebits Star Wars Vehicle)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Sized for the current Hasbro 3.75" Star Wars action figures, this motorized vehicle assembles (and disassembles) with modular, magnetized parts and features a casing for LittleBits parts that make it run! Built out of parts salvaged from defeated Rebel Alliance ships, scavengers on Jakku use vehicles such as this to collect scrap and defend their claim from rival scrappers. This unofficial toy is an original design made in homage to the release of The Force Awakens and our entry into the LittleBits Bit-Wars challenge.The model was designed in TinkerCAD where you can find and hack it. If you make variants or more modular pieces, we want to see pics! This was a joint-project with my IGG co-founder, Jeremy Larsen. We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested to help fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of toys and gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...) Enjoy! https://youtu.be/Np0HpW5MxdQ

description.text: This twisted ball Christmas ornament was designed by me using Blender 3-D and was inspired by this similar ornament here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:189704. The images were a test run that was scaled down to 80 percent of the full-size. It was printed on a PrintrBot Metal Plus using PLA. It came out quite fuzzy but could be cleaned up easily with an emery board or fingernail file. Photo courtesy Rick Ruiz. Updated this collection to include the bottle split in half. Suggest you print them with a brim adhesion during the early parts of the print. After printing, clear the brim of both parts and glue them together using superglue. Suggest using z-hop reverently 0.1 because the pointy sections tend to curl and can cause crashes.

description.text:
This part is designed to hold five light reactive resistors.  The four at the base are differentially shaded by the X and their values are used to point the array directly toward the brightest light source.  The fifth sensor located at the top of the X is used to disable the device in the case of a cloud obscuring the sun. This prevents the system from searching and pointing at the brightest spot.  
The two parts are superglued together so that the smaller part functions as an attachment bracket.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/78HyVYRCcRM

This is a spring designed for 3d printing. Watch the video to see it in action!
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UxwbQSMbEIA The more you scale the spring, the smaller the spring constant. Increasing your filament width increases the spring constant. The spring can be used in tension or compression, but it must be fairly short with comparatively thick filament width to be used in compression. It can be made extremely flexible and it is very fun to play with. It's form was discovered by accident, as it was originally auto generated support for the middle of a hollow cylinder. I'm still perfecting the design but it works quite well in it's current state. I will be uploading different sizes (and source files shortly) over the next few days. The spring was prototyped on a Fablicator.
www.Fablicator.com

Print completely hollow, no shells. Just turn fill OFF.
Adjusting your extruded width will alter the spring properties. Also, scaling the spring will alter it's properties. 
Have fun.

comments.text: It depends on the type of plastic you use. Some plastics are quite viscous once melted, in particular, high strength glass-filled plastics. If it doesn't flow well it won't completely fill a cavity and you'll get what is known as a short fill. More runny plastics flow better (obviously) but they have more of a tendency to flash (get forced out between the joins of the moulding). Its swings and roundabouts, really. The world of injection moulding can be complicated.

description.text:
** update Dec 30, 2015 - Made them a bit wider so that they would be able to take a bit more abuse and keep bed in place longer.
Print 4 of these with a flexible filament (I've used ninjaflex) and put them in between the print bed and the printers frame. 
I based this off of a forum post where someone used spring/locking washers to do the same thing. I'll link to it here if I can find it again.
I'm not sure how long it'll keep the bed level (before the ninjaflex breaks down), but so far it seems to work well. If it doesn't keep the bed level for a long period of time, the design is easy enough to make beefier... and easy enough to print replacements.
Check out Misc notes for tips on getting a level print bed.

Notes: Printed on printrbot Simple makers kit 1405 I used this ninjaflex guide I made to prevent the ninjaflex from getting tangled up when printing. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1159884 Try 15mm/s under all settings for print speeds HOW TO LEVEL YOUR PRINTER After you install your rubber compensators there are a few ways to manually level your printbed (I'm assuming you have an auto level... otherwise use paper to judge how close your hotend is from your printbed). I'm also assuming you have setup your autolevel probe so it wont drive into your printbed and damage it. Method 1: Using G-code
  • home your printer (X, Y, & Z).
  • type G29 in your gcode editor - read the points that are shown in the log and adjust the screws on your printrbot to try and get them to all be equal (note that the last number is shown twice in Repetier)
  • If your printrbot only takes three points, you can home your Y-axis and type G30 in your Gcode editor to get a fourth point.... sometimes I find this number is off though... maybe because it's not part of the sequence of G29
    • Method 2: Manual adjustments (If you're not happy with the results above)
    1: Home your printers X and Y axies.
    2: Turn your Z-axis by hand closer to your build plate (counter clockwise) until the LED lights-up on the autolevel probe.
    3: Turn your Zaxis Clockwise by hand (feel how many clicks it takes) until you the LED turns off (usually takes 4 clicks for me)
    4: Carefully move the probe to another corner, if the auto-probes LED is still off, move on to the next step, otherwise (If the LED turned on) tighten this corners screw a bit and move back to step1.
    5: Turn the Z-Axis by hand (feeling how many clicks it takes) until the LED turns on... it should take the same amount of clicks that it took from step 3... if it took more clicks to turn it on, you have to loosen the screw for that corner, if it took less clicks then you need to screw that corner in a bit.
    6: Keep doing this until your bed is level.
  • After you've completed this for every corner, you can type G29 into your Gcode editor to see how level your bed is

title: prusa i3 Zonestar p802 fan duct upgrade

description.text:
ok skipped a few experimental versions.. now up to V10 Latest version modeled with CFD to improve cooling at the tip of the extruder head.
I have managed to print some very small delicate parts as a result and the quality is definitely better. the design blows air from both sides with a slight asymmetry in order to get the 2 paths to pass closer to the tip. there are supports in the model that improve the printing of the V section under the fan these are designed for a 0.3mm nozzle diameter and worked quite well, they are easily removed with a knife or cutters. Previous versions upgrades fan cooler head, supposed to work like an air amplifier, I think it works well, consistent cooling all round head. (the original only cooled from one side) V5 now uploaded
Massive increase in airflow compared to v4 (the fan speed can be reduced as a result)
one thing to beware of I have had to move the x endstop as the cooler can now hit the z lead-screw otherwise. pictures in blue.. X carrage endstop added
Have added printed x endstop that mounts on the 40mm extruder cooler fan. this stops the wider fan duct from hitting the z lead-screws without any further modification. Apologies to anyone who downloaded the V3 it should have been V4, the STL was out of date, this is fixed now. one tip, if you're printing this and your prints are currently stringy then you'll want to pick them off before it covers the top layer otherwise it's hard to clean out the internals.. I have experimented with cutting the supports/nozzles out of the ring and you can increase airflow. but I'm not sure if it's worth the effort. I printed in PLA and to protect it against melting I have put foil tape on it to reflect the heat from the extruder. this may not be necessary, but I thought it worth the effort.
I've put a picture of the V2 with cut holes to show how I've added the foil tape. the V4 (that's in the STL) is much better for airflow and footprint.

comments.author: bunjatec

comments.text:
I did a thin feature extrude to create vertical ribs, and then I chamfered everything..
to cut into the side of the revolve I did an extrude to create the input duct and then did a cut extrude inside to clear a path through.
for the radial channels I cut one using a cut extrude and then did a circular pattern to replicate.

title: Phaser (TOS Type II) in two pieces for printing

description.text: The Phaser model that is the parent looked good but also looked like a support nightmare. I resized it a bit and split it so you could print the halves and glue them together.

Print both halves. Glue together.  
There are three files: one plate and then both sides separate.  
Watch out for warping! The barrel doesn't have a lot of contact area and if it warps it won't fit together well. I may try printing with a brim.  
The 50% sized print did pretty well on fitting together.

title: Battery Spot Welding Fixture - 18650, AA, AAA

description.text: These are holders that you can use when spot welding 18650, AA and AAA batteries together. I started with a 3D printed version of this: http://www.aliexpress.com/item/18650-battery-welding-fixture-18650-battery-fixed-clamp-18650-Battery-Fixture-Clamp-for-2-6-batteries/1907351540.html Then realized it was super hard to keep everything steady while pressing down on the batteries. Especially AAAs! So I created pockets and a wider base. I kept room for passing wires back and forth between Negative and Positive sides of your batteries as well. You can flip the design over and access the bottom of your batteries as well! I also put a slit on both sides and you can use small clamps to really hold things tight! Depending on how well dialed in your 3D printer is, you may have to scale up or down by 1% or less to get the perfect fit. I actually used the Horizontal Size Compensation set to -.05mm in Simplify3D to get them a little less snug then they were designed. It will depend on the batteries you are using and how thick of a wrapper they have. You may have to do some very very minor filing if you don't have good control of your seams.

title: Marble bearings (aka: Simplest filament holder ever)

description.text: * Updated: I took Austin's advice and added a top to enclose the marbles since some filament spools aren't smooth enough to rest on the marbles alone. I also took out some faces so they would slide better when nested.** I wanted a filament holder that wouldn't result in yet another thing crowding my desk. If your desk lamp has a skinny pole and you can figure out how to take it apart why not use the lamp to hold your filament?! Print one of these, fill with marbles, put your filament on top and put your lamp back together. Print a couple and stack your filament. The end result is that your spools turn like butta and your desk is free of clutta. (couldn't resist)

title: Single/dual Bowden extruders with mounting for Fabrikator or other RepRap

description.text:
This is my take on a complete bowden setup for a Turnigy printer. It utilises the existing parts from the direct drive that comes with the printer. You may have to source some additional parts if you want a twin nozzle setup or if you are making this for another flavour of RepRap. A mount is provided so that it can be securely and conveniently attached to the Fabrikator. Also a replacement faceplate for the fabrikator using E3D extruders.
Apart from the printed parts and the bits rescued from the existing setup you may need some of the following: (Quantities for single extruder)
14 mm hobbed pulley
13 mm bearing
4 m3 x 20mm
3 m3 x 8mm
Shaft with circlips and washers 5mm. If you cannot locate one like this then a 5mm bolt with self locking nut will do, cut to length.
Nema 17 or similar E3D Chimera dual hot end, bowden version
E3D V6 single hot end, bowden version (or Chinese equiv) Instructions: Dismantle the direct drive face plate and rescue the hobbed wheel, the bearing and its 2 washers.
If you are making a dual extruder you will need to find a source for an additional set of these parts. Print the extruders. I have tested ABS and PET for suitable flexibility, but cannot vouch for PLA being suitable...although it should be okay.
Print one or two extruders, a left hand and right hand option are given so you can ring the changes as to how you mount them. Thread a 3mm bolt through the tensioning holes and a captive nut at the other end. I used a bolt with a very wide head, but if you cannot locate one of these then use a washer.
The tension should be just about right without tightening the bolt, but if you need more pressure tighten up a bit. If the filament starts getting marked it is too tight, slacken off until the filament comes through smooth. The plastic (ABS or PET) has enough elasticity to make a spring redundant, but by all means use a spring if you want! Tap the large hole to 9mm, you dont need a special tap. An ordinary bolt would do as it is only plastic.
Screw in the Bowden attachment. Insert the bearing as per photo on the shaft with washers either side of the bearing (not essential) Secure with circlip. If you cannot locate a shaft just use a M5 bolt.
Attach the stepper with 4 m3 x20mm bolts and you are done. Now print the appropriate mount, single or double and brackets. Now attach the extruder(s) to the printer using the mount which is affixed using 2 existing self tappers as per photo. Use m3 x 8mm bolts to secure the motors. I mounted it at the back so the existing arrangement for the filament drums can be used as per original design Now print the faceplate. The single is configured for the E3D V6 hot end. The double is for the E3D "Chimera" dual hot end. Affix as per photos and cable tie the wires to the printed attachments. Make sure everything is firm and rigid.
Punch out the 2 neodymium magnets from the old hot end cover. Force these into the holes of the part fan mount.
Attach the part fan with these magnets. If you are using 2 extruders there is no longer a configurable power output for the fan on the Ramps board. You will need a ramps 1.4 fan extender, search on ebay. Now all you need do is feed Teflon tube from the extruder to the hot end (x2) and you are ready to configure your machine for twin nozzles. You could struggle with the basic Marlin but Marlin X2, repetier or marlinkimbra are easier.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Turnigy Fabrikator

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

40%

Notes: I used PET and also tested ABS, these should be fine for flexibility. I havnt tried PLA but it should be OK

author: chrishornby

description.text: A box for the 3x3 cube puzzle. It seemed like a nice simple shape to start my 3D printing experiments with. Is the 3x3 puzzle an ancestor? I've added it anyway just in case.

Cheapest easiest recycled-trash pellet hopper for your Filastruder.  
Cannibalize a soda bottle, only basic caveman tools required.  
No reason it won't work with a 2L bottle for those of you with lots of pellets to extrude. Might need to cannibalize a hanger to keep it steady though.

Step 1: Cut the bottom out of your average soda or water bottle.
Step 2: Heat the mouth with a stove, candle, heat gun, etc and shape the opening with a pair of pliers until it will fit in the hopper of your filastruder.
Step 3: Insert bottle into hopper opening, make sure it fits snugly and doesn't wobble around.
Step 4: 'Strude.

comments.text: Is the opening of the bottle wide enough so that it doesn't jamp if it is filled up with pellets ?
comments.author: punkrockseb

comments.text: The bottle opening is plenty wide. It doesn't need to be compressed much in order to fit. Honestly you could probably grind the bottle mouth down a little bit and it would fit better, but I went for the fastest easiest way to get it in there. Once I find time I will make a printable threaded hopper so you can just screw in a bottle.

Clamp to hold items on 15mm extrusion from the side.  Use a 6mm long hex-socket-head M3 screw to mount to rail.  A longer M3 screw connects to a nut embedded in the lower part for the clamping mechanism.
The print shown was not very clean, but it worked quite well as a clamp to hold a backing sheet on the print bed.  At this location, we could not use an attachment on top of the rail, since the tabs holding the main glass bed in place occupy those locations.  The clamp needed to attach to the outside of the rail.
Mounts made to hold Anderson Power-pole Connections in place. Used in our FTC Robots. One version holds two sets of Connections. The Mini holds one pair. More to come.

title: Cobblebot Little Monster Full Graphics Mount

description.text: I designed this so that I could mount the Full Graphics LCD to the top of the 80x20 Extrusion using two of the M5x8 bolts and T-Nuts. The Case for the Full Graphics Smart Controller that I printed was http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:87250 and I just drilled out the holes on the front part and used four M3x50 bolts/nuts, then cut the two bottom ones so they wouldn't hit the extrusion. This should work on any 8020 extrusion, not just the Cobblebot Little Monster 3D printer.

author: Pierrimus

description.text: This is the Oscillation Overthruster from the 1984 film, The Adventures of Buckaroo Banzai Across the 8th Dimension! This is one model I've worked long and hard on. It's a VERY difficult model due to all the complex angles and shapes involved. But this is a very good approximation of the Overthruster and was modeled to scale from a prop replica so it should be the correct size as well. As of March 2016, the Oscillation Overthruster is printable! I added four new STL files: The main body, the extra parts for the other side, and brass and black trim pieces. I printed these (very colorfully) so you can see which piece goes where. I'll soon print them in silver, gold, and black for a more accurate look. But we're really getting somewhere! Please comment and let me know what you think and if you're able to do anything more with it. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hb3H8fYMPKC

title: R2D2 - This is the Droid You're Looking For

description.text:
Please watch this video for more information: https://youtu.be/hH4L06uxcRU The survey for my next project has been closed. I'll have a video posted shortly detailing the winner and my plans to create it! This is a 3D Printed R2D2 powered with an Arduino. I started out sketching things on note cards, after that I looked up a bunch of reference images on Google to work out the dimensions, then I went to Tinkercad to start modeling it out. After that I printed the parts out using PLA on my Robo 3D Printer. The biggest prints are the body that took around 10 hours and the head that took about 6 hours to print. The rest of the parts took anywhere from 2-3 hours. The whole project totaled about 30 hours of printing time. I printed everything at 0.3mm layer height but the quality can be improved if you decrease that. After it printed I handed it off to my wife so she could paint it. She picked up some plastic spray primer to help the paint stick. Then she painted on the details with acrylic paints and a brush. Then she gave it a clear coat afterwards to avoid damage to the paint job. It has 2 stepper motors to drive it, a servo motor to turn the head, a bluetooth module for communication, and an LED for his head/eye. You can check out my breadboard layout and code below. Breadboard: https://www.dropbox.com/s/oxbjlmuvm6jshlf/R2%20breadboard.png?dl=0
Arduino Code: https://www.dropbox.com/s/ghlrpljariwyami/r2d2code.txt?dl=0 Disclaimer: This isn't a fully completed project, so make sure you have fairly good knowledge of electronics as it will take some upgrading to get working 100% correctly. I have a video posted that details the assembly process a bit more and have links to all the components I used, link to it in the video on this page. I had a lot of fun making this. If you build one I'd love to see it! I'm also going to be adding another project on here that is a non-electronic version of R2D2 in case you just want a cool looking R2 sitting around. :)
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1213273 I've also made the Tinkercad files for this model and the non-electronic version available.
Electronic Version: http://bit.ly/1MEpbgb
Non-Electronic Version: http://bit.ly/1IAtnCO

description.text:
I designed this RAMPS case originally for to mount 2 25 mm fans on the side to blow across the stepper drivers for mounting to the 8020 extrusion on my Cobblebot Little Monster 3D Printer. I have made a modification since this print to add another hole in the sides for the zip ties. This uses four of the M5x8 mm bolts and T-Nuts to mount it to the extrusion. You'll need six of the M3x10 mm bolts to mount the 25 mm fans. 
There is also a version that mounts just a 40 mm fan to the top portion. 
One of the things I don't like about other RAMPS cases is they don't ever seem to leave you space for the wires. That is why the top portion is totally open in this design.

The little finger from the http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/anthromod/3d-printed-robotic-hand/
We originally said we'd share the finger joints, but thought hey why not just share a complete finger instead. This is effectively the finger that went out for the Â£10 and Â£15 reward tiers.

Other ingredients:
20+cm of flexible wire. I used AFW 7x7 Surflon Micro Supreme 40lb.
Rubber bands. Should be small enough to stretch 10-20mm whilst supplying force. I used dreadlock hair bands!
2x 3x16mm screws. I used socket head screws.
1x 3x20mm screw.
3x M3 nuts. I used nyloc, to get a better grip.
1 crimp. AFW size #3 Ok the files are as I developed for the purpose of printing. So they're split in half because it means no overhang when printing. They also have a continuous base because some small parts would otherwise pull away. I printed at a 0.25mm layer height, which matches the base layer thickness. Once the parts have printed, it's best to remove the plastic where the screw holes are. This can be done carefully with an exacto knife. Cut off any other extra material. I printed in ABS so I glued the halves together with acetone. Pure acetone works well and avoids edge splurge you get from abs+acetone glue.
Depending on your desired finish level, it's best to sand or acetone now. Pay special attention to the hinge sides. Drill out the screw holes and tendon holes in the distal phalange. 3.2mm and 1.5mm drill bits respectively. Place the 16mm long screws through the finger joints, and the 20mm screw though the knuckle joint. Make sure the hinges can turn without resistance. Once turning freely apply the nuts to the screws. Tighten but not so far that they clamp the joints shut. Thread the tendon through the distal phalange. Thread on the crimp and form a tight loop. Shortest length nearest the finger and the longer outside. Squeeze until secure. Cut off extra tendon wire carefully as it may spring away with some speed. Thread remaining tendon through other finger sections. Now place the elastic bands on the back of the fingers joints. They should be under tension and so unable to come loose. Apply more bands until return force is what you want. Voila you should now have the beginnings of a working robot!

This is a magazine attachment for a PVC blowgun that I made. I scavenged the magazine holder off of a broken NERF Rampage then designed an adapter to connected it to my blowgun.
The blowgun doesn't function as well with the magazine on it due to the fact there is some pressure loss and air leaking but the ability to fire faster is worth it in my opinion. This was designed more as a proof of concept than a practical mod but it still turned out alright. In order to reduce the air leak a bit I wrapped the front of the dart pusher in duct tape to create a bit of a seal. Doesn't work great but its better than plastic on plastic.
I also included a rail attachment and stock adapter to attach a Barricade that acts as a nice grip for the sniper and a close range electric weapon.
I'll add the SolidWorks files soon if anyone wants to modify this to work with a different magazine holder or has any ideas on how to improve the seal or improve the design in any ways. If you have any improvement ideas but don't have access to SolidWorks let me know in the comments and I might modify the design if its a good idea and I can find the time.

title: ATP Synthase
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This model of ATP Synthase (ATPase) lets students explore how a proton concentration gradient is used to store energy in the form of ATP. Protons are placed into the protein through the hole on the topside of the membrane. The protons move into the c-subunit. After each proton is added, rotate the c-subunit. Eventually, the proton will drop out the bottom of the membrane. As the c-subunit is spun, the alpha and beta subunits will move, simulating the conformational changes that occur in order for the protein to combine ADP and Pi to form ATP.
Also included is an actin filament. A fluorescently labeled actin filament was used in the experiment that first demonstrated the spinning motion of ATP synthase. (It would be really cool to use glow in the dark filament to print this part of the model and then recreate the experiment using a UV light).

Printer:

Da Vinci Jr.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Does not matter

Infill:

5%

Notes: The only pieces that require rafts and supports is the actin filament and the hydrogen ions. All other files can be printed without rafts or supports.

Step 1: Insert the outer column into the bottom of the membrane, lining up the tabs. Step 2: Insert alpha/beta subunits into the slots in the outer column at a 90 degree angle. Step 3: Once the subunit slides in, rotate to a vertical position. Step 4: Insert axel into c-subunit. Be sure to line up the bump on the axel with the outline in the top of the subunit. Step 5: Insert axel into the outer column. Be sure that the bump on the axel lines up with the outline on the column. Step 6: Place model on frame. Optional: attach actin filament by inserting the columns on the c-subunit into the holes on the filament.
NGSS CCSS

Understanding the function of proteins is an important part of a biology course. Specifically, students need to understand the relationship between structure and function of biological molecules. This model of ATP synthase allows students to see how the structure of ATP synthase allows it to produce ATP molecules in the electron transport chain.
The model should be used after students have been taught about the structures of proteins. Students should also be familiar with the process of cellular respiration, specifically the electron transport chain in the mitochondria, ions, concentration, and diffusion.

Before using the model, be sure students understand how energy is stored in a concentration gradient and how a hydrogen ion concentration is built up in the mitochondria. 
Describe how the small balls represent protons and ask students what will happen if most of the protons are located on the upper side of the membrane.
Students can use the model to explore where these ions can go and how the c-subunit can spin in order to move the protons through the membrane.
Students should notice how the spinning of the c-subunit causes the lower section of the protein to move.
Describe how the energy of this movement is used to combine ADP and Pi to form ATP.
The discovery of the way ATPase moves can be re-enacted by using the fluorescent actin filament. Student can either be asked to design an experiment or led through how the experiment was done. The fluorescent filament was attached to the protein and its position measured over time. A fluorescent tag was added so that the scientists could measure the position with a camera (use glow in the dark filament for the actin filament and a UV light if possible)
No other materials besides the model are needed.

Objectives Students will be able to describe how the energy in a concentration gradient is transferred into the molecule ATP. Students will be able to label and describe the functions of the different subunits of the ATP synthase protein. Students will be able to describe the process by which the body creates ATP. Students will be able to describe the experiment and data used to show that ATP is a spinning protein and works much like a hydroelectric generator. Students will be able to describe the technique of fluorescence. Results Students should be able to describe the process by which the energy in a concentration gradient is converted into the chemical energy of ATP. The model will serve as a launch point for further discussion into the subunits and structure of this and other proteins. Students can research the mechanisms by which ATP is formed on the chemical level as well as the effects of toxins, drugs, and diseases on these proteins.

This is a model of the lifeguard stands that are common at the Jersey Shore.
I printed the model without support, got some stringing under the cross pieces but nothing that couldn't be cleaned up.  A print at 150% should be about the right size to match my little niece's Lego people.

UPDATE :
There was a big fail on the x-end-motor I corrected + increased space for GT2 belt This is a slight remix of Xoan's i3 ziptiedish x-end and Josef prusa's vanilla prusa where :
  • even the LM8UU are ziptied ! (2.5mm zipties work fine for this)
  • added a 10 mm hole for the Z-axis to move freely as I'm rather using my thing 1147671 for leadscrew anti-wooble purposes.
  • added a little hole on the x-end-motor for a M3 screw that will trigger the Z-endstop
    • So far I did print them but I haven't tested them as X-axis structural parts. There may be an issue with the room for the GT2 belt to move freely The source are on my github fork of Xoan/Josef Prusa : https://github.com/Gad/Prusa3-vanilla. Feel free :)

I printed one of Gecko's desk signs warning people that my 3D printer is useful for a lot of things so please don't talk to me about that damned gun thing.  But I wanted a flat one I could print and affix to the front of the rolling cart my 3D printer is on, since that's where it's the most appropriate.  
I wasn't able to get the original file, so I imported Gecko's STL into Google SketchUp, then spent ages healing surfaces and stripping out a lot of the unnecessary curves.  No matter how long I chased the flaws, Google SketchUp always remembered enough of them that the resulting model was non-manifold and beyond Netfabb's powers to fix.  In the end, I had to rebuild it from scratch, which took a fraction of the time I wasted.  Lesson learned!  
As with Gecko's original, this isn't intended as a statement about guns, but just about how annoying it is that the first and only thing everyone talks about when you bring up 3D printing is guns.
Unlike Gecko's, mine prints better with the lettering up.  No special printing requirements or instructions otherwise.

description.text:
This is a new version of last night's templates. They are half the thickness, and they should be 3/64'ths of an inch wider on the inside, because the old ones printed too small to fit over the steel tubes. I've also tweaked the height to make a faster print, and added 2 more templates:
  • A cylindrical cut for mating the front forks to the head tubes.
  • A 83.57 cut, which assuming my trig skills hold true, is the correct angle for making the front cuts of the rear forks.
    • I've also added mouse-ears because the corners were curling as I printed. Lastly, I smartened up the SCAD code a bit. Next rev will have the front forks where they attach to the frame... They're really all that's left.

• print
  • slip template over steel tube
  • mark steel with a sharpie
  • remove template
  • cut steel
  • weld

comments.text: Also, what is Spinner Guys username in the forums so I can look up what posts he has commented on?
comments.author: curious

comments.text: Thanks for the info! Even though the template for where the front arm met the spine of the trike was a hard line to follow and cut, would it give the correct angle if it was possible to follow the line to cut?
comments.author: curious

comments.text: I was going to start building this trike and wanted to know if these templates were the right size and if they worked for you?
comments.author: curious

comments.text:
um. Its complicated! I think they were good ways to mark steel, but I found that for the complex cuts, especially where the front forks meet the center spine of the trike, they led to a line that was very touch to accurately cut against. To be perfectly honest, in the end, I bought a circular saw blade from oshlun and mounted it in a compound miter saw I bought for 100 bucks (father's day sale price) at Home Despot. It cut through the steel like butter with perfect angles as long as the steel is clamped right, and I could dial in any angle, on 2 axes, to within a half-degree accuracy. The v-cut and pipe cut were tougher... one of my next projects will be a fishmouth cutter. The v-cut was annoying, but with care I was able to do it with a simple chop-saw.
I have a few suggestions though: 1) find spinner guy on G+ and look through every photo he ever posted. 2) look at the various warrior projects he's commented on, too. 3) look at http://www.instructables.com/id/Building-a-Recumbent-Bamboo-Trike-Frame/http://www.instructables.com/i... The jig he built seems to me to be the ultimate for making sure what you do rides true. 4) put about the same amount of time into making the chain's line as straight and smooth as possible. It makes a world of difference. I'm building a second trike because of the flaws I created in the first. I could cut and grind parts off then re-weld, but a neighbor wants to buy my trike as is for summer dog-sledding!
comments.author: curious

description.text:
This spool holder supports a variety of spool widths and can be disassembled and packed flat for traveling.  
I've included the OpenScad files so you can customize if you need to.

Print 2 of the Triangle-stand.stl and 2 of the crossbar.stl files.  
If you are using MakerBot spools or taller spools, print 2 of the MakerBotSpoolExtender to make the height taller.  
Then get yourself an aluminum rod from the hardware store to hold the spool.  Cut this into a 7 inch length.  (You could probably also use a wooden dowel).  
As an enhancement, you could take shelf liner and cut two strips to glue to the bottom of the triangle pieces.  This helps prevent the spool holder from slipping.

comments.text: Nice!  As the spool nears the empty state (and thus becomes lighter), do you find that this spool holder remains stable?
comments.author: TheThinker

comments.text: I've emptied at least two spools using the first prototype of this stand which was actually even lighter but I had glued the pieces together.  The biggest problem I had was the holder sliding across the table.  I fixed this by gluing some shelf liner to the bottom of the triangle pieces and this kept it from sliding.
comments.author: TheThinker

This is an experimental device to remove ticks. Put tick through the big hole - flat side against your skin. Pull along skin while pressing down to force the tick down the channel. Make sure you get the 'blades' under the head. Fortunately, we are at the end of tick season here... I make no warranties that this will actually do anything useful or keep ticks from vomiting disease into your bloodstream. If you do happen to get a tick, print it out, give it a try before you reach for the tweezers and let me know how it went. Thanks! This component is part of an open source lab library, by the Michigan Tech's Open Sustainability Technology Research Group. For similar see the Open-Source Lab How to Build Your Own Hardware and Reduce Research Costs

comments.text: I believe standard recommendation is to keep tick in a jar to show a Doctor or medic to determine what medical treatment (if anything) is needed.
comments.author: bathrobotics

comments.text: Yeah those fuckers frequently have Lyme disease which can be crippling if not properly diagnosed. The spirochetes are incredibly difficult to fight once manifested in large areas of the body, but caught early, can be treated with the same antibiotics you might take for 'normal' bacterial infection. I would definitely preserve if possible, and go out of my way to make sure I did not have characteristic bullseye pattern bite suggesting the tick had something bad.
comments.author: bathrobotics

comments.text: @maxumx Very True ! You need roatation to remove them.
comments.author: matthieuheitz

comments.text: This may work, I've used metal versions successfully. My concern is that the narrow part isn't narrow enough. Twisting is NOT required, and some sources recommend against it.
comments.author: matthieuheitz

comments.text: Looks like it could remove bee stings too
comments.author: zpj

comments.text: from a stand point of tick removal, i would say this would not be as effective as a tick key. a tick once it locks on turns its head in the hole. locking its head under the skin. grabbing the tick then rotating it would be more effective then trying to cut it off like this here.
comments.author: maxumx

comments.text: I have used metal versions of these with success. Get the tick head in the narrow part of the hole and pull away, parallel to the skin.
comments.author: maxumx

comments.text: what is a tick ? it sounds horrible
comments.author: luciandepold

comments.text: You do not want to know.

comments.text: I could have done with this when I lived in Merley near Wimbourne Minster in the UK near the home of the dreaded Blandford tick with a really nasty bite!

description.text: This is my logo project. All you have to do is choose a logo, or even a picture that you like, and make it in 3d. This is an easy, creative project for anyone.
Step 1 The first step is to pic a logo. Step 2 In this step, design your logo. Step 3 3d print your logo.

Lessons Students would better learn how to use their design software. Ages Anyone who can use their software can make this easy project. Anything Needed? Anyone can learn how to do it. All you need is the software, and a 3d printer. (Also a computer) Accomplish/ Grade You should have better understanding of your software and printer after this project. It should be graded by: 10 points for the design, 5 points for how it printed.
